issue.title: chore: make log topics conistent with nim-chronicles style
issue.body:
It all started with me looking for a way to reduce the verbosity of the test cases in the CI. I hunch that test execution time is also impacted by the immense amount of logs the code is writing to the stdout.

Diving into `nim-chronicles` code, I noticed that the topics filtering mechanism works with "whole words" separated by spaces. Checking the `nim-libp2p` code base, together with some tests passing the `-d:"chronicles_disabled_topics=libp2p,pubsubprotobuf"` flag has confirmed it.

NOTE: I also noticed that in some cases, `nim-chronicles` is not respecting the `logScope: topics = "<topics>"` statement, logging without the `topics` tags.

-----

Some of the rules in the [coding guide](https://hackmd.io/5oIVOuQcSM2WKrnDLUPcpg#Logging) might need to be updated to be compatible with `nim-chronicles`. These are the rules I have synthesized for better logging:

* Log topics should contain "whole words" separated by spaces. In the case of a composed word, it should follow the `snake_case` style.
* Log topics should be ordered from more general to less general (e.g., `waku node message_store sqlite_store`)
* The modules' log topics within `waku` module should have `waku` as the first topic. This will allow any user of waku (as a library) to mute all logs coming by filtering the `waku` topic. The `whisper` module is the exception.
* The apps' log topics should start with the name of the app (e.g., `wakunode2 rest`)
* Waku protocols' log topics should be specified without the "waku" prefix (e.g., `waku filter client`)

issue.title: ci: use git clean instead of cleanWs() function
issue.body:
This is a continuation of attempts to fix provlems with Windows CI hosts getting into a broken state due to `.git` directory becoming a file for random submodules for unknown reason.

Instead of relying on Jenkins functionality of `cleanWs()` function provided by the [Workspace Cleanup Plugin](https://plugins.jenkins.io/ws-cleanup) we use Git which should be more reliable, and possibly also speed up the initial checkout of the repo and submodules.

Previous issues:
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/7968
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/8046

issue.title: chore(examples): add pubsub example with production env
issue.body:
Simple pubsub example to showcase how `nwaku` can be used. Some notes:
* Add a new `example` with two codes: `publisher` and `subscriber`.
* Both publisher and subscriber connect to our fleet, discovering news peers and connecting to them.
* Publisher and subscriber can run on different machines, and is not a requirements that they are discoverable.
* Default pubsub topic is used.
* Bare minimum code that a client can use to leverage waku network.

issue.title: feat(wakunode2): support configuration via environment variables
issue.body:
As part of the effort to conform to the [twelve-factor app](https://12factor.net/) principles. And regarding the configuration, [the III principle](https://12factor.net/config), this PR adds support to configure the `wakunode2` app via environment variables.

This PR resolves #1198 

------

Environment variables should be prefixed by the app's name. For example, to set the `--tcp-port` configuration we should call `wakunode2` binary as follows:

```bash
WAKUNODE2_TCP_PORT=65000 ./build/wakunode2
```

And this is the configuration precedence order (each item takes precedence over the item below it):

1. Commandline options/flags
2. Environment variables
3. Configuration file (currently, only TOML is supported)
4. Default value

This precedence order also aligns with other languages' de facto standards like [Go's Viper](https://github.com/spf13/viper#:~:text=Viper%20uses%20the,default).

-----

In `nim-cofutils` the environment variables support is intended to be provided using `nim-serialization` (actually, `envvar_serialization`). So yes, `nim-confutils` documentation (a.k.a. README.md) is outdated. And added to that, the code that parses the environment variables in the `master` branch is not working as expected.

This left me with only one option: "fork" the code. At some point, we'll want to upstream it back to `nim-confutils` repo. 

So, the result is:

- [x] Add the "envvar" config file in `wakunode2` as another configuration source
- [x] Fix environment variables name construction (in `waku/common/envvar_serialization` fork)
- [x] Mimick Toml's modules in `nim-confutils` to support deserialization (in `waku/common/confutils/envvar`)

issue.title: fix: replace nim's std/nre with nim-regex library
issue.body:
Nim's standard library `std/nre` loads at runtime (via `dlopen()`) the `libpcre.so.3`. 

This is not portable enough. This shared library name differs depending on the Linux distributions (e.g., in Linux Arch, the shared object is named `libpcre.so.0`).

- [x] Replace `std/nre` with `nitely/nim-regex` library

For more context, check [this forum thread](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008) and [this comment](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008#:~:text=We%20could%20maybe%20adopt%20nim%2Dregex%20into%20the%20stdlib%20and%20deprecate%20both%20re%20and%20nre...)

issue.title: Added distinct ColourHash type
issue.body:
## What's Changed?

I've replaced references to `[][]int` that are used directly as a `ColourHash`, to use an explicit `[][2]int`

## Why Change?

This change codifies that a `ColourHash` is a slice of `[2]int`, as consuming code depends on the inner slice having exactly 2 indexes.

issue.title: feat(Message): fallback to import message content if necessary
issue.body:
Messages are parsed to transform markdown to something that can be rendered in a formatted way.

When this happens, the parsed text is applied to a message's `text` property inside desktop.

There was no formatted message support for imported discord messages, so we were relying purely on `discordMessage.content`.

However, now formatting support is pending in status-go here: https://github.com/status-im/status-go/pull/2933

This means, once this lands, we can simply rely on `messsageItem.text`.

I'm adding this guard here such that this will continue to work without the feature in status-go, but once the feature in status-go lands, desktop will automatically adapt.

Closes #8086

issue.title: feat(testlib): add enable/disable test debug utils
issue.body:
Following Javascript's Jest idea of _disabling a test by adding an 'x' before/after the test keyword_ (see [Jest docs](https://jestjs.io/docs/next/api#describeskipname-fn:~:text=Also%20under%20the%20aliases%3A%20it.skip(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20xit(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20and%20xtest(name%2C%20fn))):

> When you are maintaining a large codebase, you may sometimes find a test that is temporarily broken for some reason. If you want to skip running this test, but you don't want to delete this code, you can use test.skip to specify some tests to skip.

So in our case this is how to use the new test debug utils:

1. Import the `./testlib/testutils` module in your test suite file
2. Add a 'x' either before or after the test case/suite keyword: `xtest`, `xasyncTest`, `xsuite`, `xprocSuite`, etc.
3. Run the test suite. The tests you marked with an ✖️ won't be executed.

**IMPORTANT:** Do not forget to re-enable the test cases disabled during your debugging session before committing your changes.

issue.title: chore: make log topics conistent with nim-chronicles style
issue.body:
It all started with me looking for a way to reduce the verbosity of the test cases in the CI. I hunch that test execution time is also impacted by the immense amount of logs the code is writing to the stdout.

Diving into `nim-chronicles` code, I noticed that the topics filtering mechanism works with "whole words" separated by spaces. Checking the `nim-libp2p` code base, together with some tests passing the `-d:"chronicles_disabled_topics=libp2p,pubsubprotobuf"` flag has confirmed it.

NOTE: I also noticed that in some cases, `nim-chronicles` is not respecting the `logScope: topics = "<topics>"` statement, logging without the `topics` tags.

-----

Some of the rules in the [coding guide](https://hackmd.io/5oIVOuQcSM2WKrnDLUPcpg#Logging) might need to be updated to be compatible with `nim-chronicles`. These are the rules I have synthesized for better logging:

* Log topics should contain "whole words" separated by spaces. In the case of a composed word, it should follow the `snake_case` style.
* Log topics should be ordered from more general to less general (e.g., `waku node message_store sqlite_store`)
* The modules' log topics within `waku` module should have `waku` as the first topic. This will allow any user of waku (as a library) to mute all logs coming by filtering the `waku` topic. The `whisper` module is the exception.
* The apps' log topics should start with the name of the app (e.g., `wakunode2 rest`)
* Waku protocols' log topics should be specified without the "waku" prefix (e.g., `waku filter client`)

issue.title: ci: use git clean instead of cleanWs() function
issue.body:
This is a continuation of attempts to fix provlems with Windows CI hosts getting into a broken state due to `.git` directory becoming a file for random submodules for unknown reason.

Instead of relying on Jenkins functionality of `cleanWs()` function provided by the [Workspace Cleanup Plugin](https://plugins.jenkins.io/ws-cleanup) we use Git which should be more reliable, and possibly also speed up the initial checkout of the repo and submodules.

Previous issues:
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/7968
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/8046

issue.title: feat(wakunode2): support configuration via environment variables
issue.body:
As part of the effort to conform to the [twelve-factor app](https://12factor.net/) principles. And regarding the configuration, [the III principle](https://12factor.net/config), this PR adds support to configure the `wakunode2` app via environment variables.

This PR resolves #1198 

------

Environment variables should be prefixed by the app's name. For example, to set the `--tcp-port` configuration we should call `wakunode2` binary as follows:

```bash
WAKUNODE2_TCP_PORT=65000 ./build/wakunode2
```

And this is the configuration precedence order (each item takes precedence over the item below it):

1. Commandline options/flags
2. Environment variables
3. Configuration file (currently, only TOML is supported)
4. Default value

This precedence order also aligns with other languages' de facto standards like [Go's Viper](https://github.com/spf13/viper#:~:text=Viper%20uses%20the,default).

-----

In `nim-cofutils` the environment variables support is intended to be provided using `nim-serialization` (actually, `envvar_serialization`). So yes, `nim-confutils` documentation (a.k.a. README.md) is outdated. And added to that, the code that parses the environment variables in the `master` branch is not working as expected.

This left me with only one option: "fork" the code. At some point, we'll want to upstream it back to `nim-confutils` repo. 

So, the result is:

- [x] Add the "envvar" config file in `wakunode2` as another configuration source
- [x] Fix environment variables name construction (in `waku/common/envvar_serialization` fork)
- [x] Mimick Toml's modules in `nim-confutils` to support deserialization (in `waku/common/confutils/envvar`)

issue.title: fix: replace nim's std/nre with nim-regex library
issue.body:
Nim's standard library `std/nre` loads at runtime (via `dlopen()`) the `libpcre.so.3`. 

This is not portable enough. This shared library name differs depending on the Linux distributions (e.g., in Linux Arch, the shared object is named `libpcre.so.0`).

- [x] Replace `std/nre` with `nitely/nim-regex` library

For more context, check [this forum thread](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008) and [this comment](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008#:~:text=We%20could%20maybe%20adopt%20nim%2Dregex%20into%20the%20stdlib%20and%20deprecate%20both%20re%20and%20nre...)

## What's Changed?

I've replaced references to `[][]int` that are used directly as a `ColourHash`, to use an explicit `[][2]int`

## Why Change?

This change codifies that a `ColourHash` is a slice of `[2]int`, as consuming code depends on the inner slice having exactly 2 indexes.

issue.title: feat(Message): fallback to import message content if necessary
issue.body:
Messages are parsed to transform markdown to something that can be rendered in a formatted way.

When this happens, the parsed text is applied to a message's `text` property inside desktop.

There was no formatted message support for imported discord messages, so we were relying purely on `discordMessage.content`.

However, now formatting support is pending in status-go here: https://github.com/status-im/status-go/pull/2933

This means, once this lands, we can simply rely on `messsageItem.text`.

I'm adding this guard here such that this will continue to work without the feature in status-go, but once the feature in status-go lands, desktop will automatically adapt.

Closes #8086

issue.title: feat(testlib): add enable/disable test debug utils
issue.body:
Following Javascript's Jest idea of _disabling a test by adding an 'x' before/after the test keyword_ (see [Jest docs](https://jestjs.io/docs/next/api#describeskipname-fn:~:text=Also%20under%20the%20aliases%3A%20it.skip(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20xit(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20and%20xtest(name%2C%20fn))):

> When you are maintaining a large codebase, you may sometimes find a test that is temporarily broken for some reason. If you want to skip running this test, but you don't want to delete this code, you can use test.skip to specify some tests to skip.

So in our case this is how to use the new test debug utils:

1. Import the `./testlib/testutils` module in your test suite file
2. Add a 'x' either before or after the test case/suite keyword: `xtest`, `xasyncTest`, `xsuite`, `xprocSuite`, etc.
3. Run the test suite. The tests you marked with an ✖️ won't be executed.

**IMPORTANT:** Do not forget to re-enable the test cases disabled during your debugging session before committing your changes.

issue.title: chore: make log topics conistent with nim-chronicles style
issue.body:
It all started with me looking for a way to reduce the verbosity of the test cases in the CI. I hunch that test execution time is also impacted by the immense amount of logs the code is writing to the stdout.

Diving into `nim-chronicles` code, I noticed that the topics filtering mechanism works with "whole words" separated by spaces. Checking the `nim-libp2p` code base, together with some tests passing the `-d:"chronicles_disabled_topics=libp2p,pubsubprotobuf"` flag has confirmed it.

NOTE: I also noticed that in some cases, `nim-chronicles` is not respecting the `logScope: topics = "<topics>"` statement, logging without the `topics` tags.

-----

Some of the rules in the [coding guide](https://hackmd.io/5oIVOuQcSM2WKrnDLUPcpg#Logging) might need to be updated to be compatible with `nim-chronicles`. These are the rules I have synthesized for better logging:

* Log topics should contain "whole words" separated by spaces. In the case of a composed word, it should follow the `snake_case` style.
* Log topics should be ordered from more general to less general (e.g., `waku node message_store sqlite_store`)
* The modules' log topics within `waku` module should have `waku` as the first topic. This will allow any user of waku (as a library) to mute all logs coming by filtering the `waku` topic. The `whisper` module is the exception.
* The apps' log topics should start with the name of the app (e.g., `wakunode2 rest`)
* Waku protocols' log topics should be specified without the "waku" prefix (e.g., `waku filter client`)

issue.title: ci: use git clean instead of cleanWs() function
issue.body:
This is a continuation of attempts to fix provlems with Windows CI hosts getting into a broken state due to `.git` directory becoming a file for random submodules for unknown reason.

Instead of relying on Jenkins functionality of `cleanWs()` function provided by the [Workspace Cleanup Plugin](https://plugins.jenkins.io/ws-cleanup) we use Git which should be more reliable, and possibly also speed up the initial checkout of the repo and submodules.

Previous issues:
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/7968
- https://github.com/status-im/status-desktop/pull/8046

issue.title: feat(wakunode2): support configuration via environment variables
issue.body:
As part of the effort to conform to the [twelve-factor app](https://12factor.net/) principles. And regarding the configuration, [the III principle](https://12factor.net/config), this PR adds support to configure the `wakunode2` app via environment variables.

This PR resolves #1198 

------

Environment variables should be prefixed by the app's name. For example, to set the `--tcp-port` configuration we should call `wakunode2` binary as follows:

```bash
WAKUNODE2_TCP_PORT=65000 ./build/wakunode2
```

And this is the configuration precedence order (each item takes precedence over the item below it):

1. Commandline options/flags
2. Environment variables
3. Configuration file (currently, only TOML is supported)
4. Default value

This precedence order also aligns with other languages' de facto standards like [Go's Viper](https://github.com/spf13/viper#:~:text=Viper%20uses%20the,default).

-----

In `nim-cofutils` the environment variables support is intended to be provided using `nim-serialization` (actually, `envvar_serialization`). So yes, `nim-confutils` documentation (a.k.a. README.md) is outdated. And added to that, the code that parses the environment variables in the `master` branch is not working as expected.

This left me with only one option: "fork" the code. At some point, we'll want to upstream it back to `nim-confutils` repo. 

So, the result is:

- [x] Add the "envvar" config file in `wakunode2` as another configuration source
- [x] Fix environment variables name construction (in `waku/common/envvar_serialization` fork)
- [x] Mimick Toml's modules in `nim-confutils` to support deserialization (in `waku/common/confutils/envvar`)

issue.title: fix: replace nim's std/nre with nim-regex library
issue.body:
Nim's standard library `std/nre` loads at runtime (via `dlopen()`) the `libpcre.so.3`. 

This is not portable enough. This shared library name differs depending on the Linux distributions (e.g., in Linux Arch, the shared object is named `libpcre.so.0`).

- [x] Replace `std/nre` with `nitely/nim-regex` library

For more context, check [this forum thread](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008) and [this comment](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/6008#:~:text=We%20could%20maybe%20adopt%20nim%2Dregex%20into%20the%20stdlib%20and%20deprecate%20both%20re%20and%20nre...)

- [x] Updated tests accordingly

issue.title: Added distinct ColourHash type
issue.body:
## What's Changed?

I've replaced references to `[][]int` that are used directly as a `ColourHash`, to use an explicit `[][2]int`

## Why Change?

This change codifies that a `ColourHash` is a slice of `[2]int`, as consuming code depends on the inner slice having exactly 2 indexes.

issue.title: feat(Message): fallback to import message content if necessary
issue.body:
Messages are parsed to transform markdown to something that can be rendered in a formatted way.

When this happens, the parsed text is applied to a message's `text` property inside desktop.

There was no formatted message support for imported discord messages, so we were relying purely on `discordMessage.content`.

However, now formatting support is pending in status-go here: https://github.com/status-im/status-go/pull/2933

This means, once this lands, we can simply rely on `messsageItem.text`.

I'm adding this guard here such that this will continue to work without the feature in status-go, but once the feature in status-go lands, desktop will automatically adapt.

Closes #8086

issue.title: feat(testlib): add enable/disable test debug utils
issue.body:
Following Javascript's Jest idea of _disabling a test by adding an 'x' before/after the test keyword_ (see [Jest docs](https://jestjs.io/docs/next/api#describeskipname-fn:~:text=Also%20under%20the%20aliases%3A%20it.skip(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20xit(name%2C%20fn)%2C%20and%20xtest(name%2C%20fn))):

> When you are maintaining a large codebase, you may sometimes find a test that is temporarily broken for some reason. If you want to skip running this test, but you don't want to delete this code, you can use test.skip to specify some tests to skip.

So in our case this is how to use the new test debug utils:

1. Import the `./testlib/testutils` module in your test suite file
2. Add a 'x' either before or after the test case/suite keyword: `xtest`, `xasyncTest`, `xsuite`, `xprocSuite`, etc.
3. Run the test suite. The tests you marked with an ✖️ won't be executed.

**IMPORTANT:** Do not forget to re-enable the test cases disabled during your debugging session before committing your changes.
